title: JetBlue worker faces up to 20 years in prison for booking scam
text:
A former JetBlue worker is facing up to 20 years in prison after she admitted an $800,000 scam to upgrade flights for her friends and family.

Tiffany Jenkins handed out more than 500 free upgrades over 15 months - an average of more than one a day - using her access to JetBlue's bookings database.

She converted cheap domestic flights into expensive trips around the world using a special code called 'involuntary exchange', which is meant for customers who miss flights or experience a death in the family.

The 31-year-old pleaded guilty to three counts of wire fraud in federal court in Boston, Massachusetts last Friday and will be sentenced in January.

Airline fraud: A JetBlue airplane takes off from Boston where Tiffany Jenkins pleaded guilty to an $800,000 scam in which she gave free upgrades to her friends and family

Working as a gate agent, Jenkins used the 'INVOL' code for more than 100 different passengers between July 2016 and September 2017, prosecutors said.

Passengers were initially booked on flights at the lowest available fares, often a short trip between Las Vegas and Long Beach, California.

A short time later, Jenkins would switch the booking to a completely different pair of cities at no cost to the customer, according to U.S. attorneys.

The new flights 'generally involved much more expensive international locations,' prosecutors said.

In total, she made 505 involuntary ticket exchanges in a period of 453 days, using them for 'friends, family and acquaintances'.

She was arrested in November 2018 and charged with three counts of wire fraud, which she admitted last week.

The total cost to JetBlue is believed to have been around $785,000, according to reports.

Federal judge Mark Wolf scheduled Jenkins's sentencing for January 21 next year.

She faces a maximum of 20 years in prison, three years of supervised release and a fine of up to $250,000.
description: Tiffany Jenkins converted more than 500 cheap domestic bookings into expensive flights over 15 months. She admitted wire fraud in federal court in Boston (where a JetBlue plane is seen taking off).
